page.title: 03BIOGRAPHY OF C.WATERTON.
page.content: Charles Waterton, the eccentric naturalist, explorer and taxidermist, started as a pupil at Stonyhurst College in 1796, when he was 14. When he left in 1801, his reflections were: "The day I left the Jesuits' College was one of heartfelt sorrow to me .." He turned his house, Walton Hall, into a nature reserve, building a high wall around the 259 acres. His explorations were recorded in his book, "Wanderings in South America". While at Stonyhurst he climbed one of the eagle towers and, when half way up, was told by a Jesuit to come down. That night the stone onto which he would have next clung fell to the ground, so he narrowly escaped death.The famous portrait of Waterton, featuring the stuffed cat's head resting on a book, hangs in the Top Refectory of Stonyhurst College.
